title: What’s the difference between a website and a Star Destroyer? Greebles.

last_post.content:
Having a library of UI components at your fingertips makes it easy to feel like you're ready to design - but if you don't have an underlying conceptual model, those components are as meaningful as the shiny lights on a Star Destroyer model.

Throwing some mock elements in a design can be a great way to spark conversations during discovery, but keep them out of demos (and certainly deliverables).

#UXDesign #UserResearch #UIDesign

title: GitHub - natemoo-re/tiny-decode: Decode HTML entities the browser-friendly way

last_post.content:
I just published 🤏 `tiny-decode`!

Traditionally, decoding HTML named character references requires a large table to store entity names and the code points to which they refer. Unless you take extreme care, this data can easily end up in your JavaScript bundle.

Using export conditions, `tiny-decode` only includes a few bytes in your browser bundles. Server bundles include the full table as usual.

`entities` 👉 19.64 kB gzip
`tiny-decode` 👉 0.56 kB gzip

https://github.com/natemoo-re/tiny-decode

I'm excited that we've put up a new #preprint on a project that I think of as the "thing explainer." The goal of this project was to, for a pair of biomedical entities, provide the simplest hypothesis for how they might be connected (after, of course, correcting for things like node degree, node type degree distribution, etc).

Conceptually this is simple. In reality (the parenthetical), it's pretty hard. Software & conceptual advances to make it possible.

title: This is why you should keep stateful and stateless resources together | theburningmonk.com

last_post.content:
I agree with @theburningmonk that you should generally put your stateful resources in the same stack as the rest of your application. All of this risk mitigation you're doing with a separate stack can be done for a single stack. The main reason to use separate stacks is if it fits in with an existing risk mitigation strategy you're using.

We can also take a vector space and forget which point counts as zero, or the 'origin', getting something called an 'affine space':

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affine_space

This is actually a somewhat better picture of the space we live in than a vector space, since there's not really any special point that acts like the center of the universe!

Every affine space is free! And so are the things like affine spaces where we use a division ring instead of a field.

title: Furby 1998 source code : David Hampton, Wayne Schulz : Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming : Internet Archive

last_post.content:
The Furby source code is public and heavily commented. For example, it turns the microphone off when the motors are running.

Furby was the 1998 version of ChatGPT and tons of people thought it actually slowly learned English words. The NSA was alarmed. However it turned out the "learning" process was just on a timer and the "microphone" only triggers on loud sounds.
https://archive.org/details/furby-source

The journal Meta-Psychology envisions a radically open way to publish.

It is free to publish in, open access, open peer review. Data and materials are required to be made publicly available. All statistical analyses are reproduced by their team to ensure reproducibility. They allow "evolving papers" where updates, replications, commentaries are added as links in the original paper webpage.
